history.content:
I think you should be able to self-study the probability portion of CS 70, since you'd have enough mathematical maturity for it (when I took 70, it was mostly discrete probability stuff, which isn't too bad to self-study imo). So yes, if you put in a bit more effort, I think you'd be fine  in 126.

------

Completely disagree with above answer; ee126 is incredibly self-selecting and most students taking it have more experience than you've listed (including CS70 and often ee127/cs189). If you haven't taken 70, prob140/stat134 would be better.

I think you should be able to self-study the probability portion of CS 70, since you'd have enough mathematical maturity for it (when I took 70, it was mostly discrete probability stuff, which isn't too bad to self-study imo). So yes, if you put in a bit more effort, I think you'd be fine  in 126.

I think you should be able to self-study the probability portion of CS 70, since you'd have enough mathematical maturity for it (when I took it, it was mostly discrete probability stuff, which isn't too bad to self-study imo). So yes, if you put in a bit more effort, I think you'd be fine  in 126.

children.subject: I think strong probability foundation is a must for 126. I saw many students took this class have a strong intuition about probability puzzles and many of them are at TA’s level of understanding CS70 theory. So I think taking CS70 and really understand the material is the key. Maybe 134 plus 70 is even better, LOL.

history.content:
People should take EECS126 as an entry-level upper-division course (like 170) after they have completed their lower-division: namely Math 53 and the 16A, 16B, 70 trilogy as well as the 61A, 61B, 61C trilogy. 

Of course, students with that background will have to work hard and will learn a lot, including solidifying their foundations as well as thinking, problem solving skills, and further building maturity. There should be soreness, but not pain or injury. Having to work hard and putting in time doesn't mean that you are not prepared. This is Berkeley after all. You are here to work hard and grow.

Because EECS126 has been scaling in size slower than intrinsic demand, there have been some cohorts that include people with course inversions (where they are taking 126 *after* courses that they should really have taken after 126). While it can sometimes be intimidating to be in a classroom with others who have more background, the course staff in EECS126 care about your success. It's not about what others know. 

For students who don't have 70 (like the OP), the question is just whether they have the mathematical background and prior exposure to probability to succeed. Math 55 plus the entry-level-upper-div triad of 104, 113, and 110 should be more than sufficient. Especially with ds100 in the mix as well.  Take EECS126. The probability review at the beginning will be less review, but you'll have stronger proof muscles to make up for it.

Hi! I'm currently a senior double majoring in applied math and cs. I've taken math 55, 104, 113, 110, ds100, ee16a and ee16b. But I haven't taken cs70, which is a prereq for ee126. Despite that, would it be possible to do well in ee126 or should I choose prob 140/ stat 134 instead?
history.subject: EE126 vs prob 140 vs stat134
